entry.et: Middle English, from Old English losian to perish, lose, from los destruction; akin to Old English lēosan to lose; akin to Old Norse losa to loosen, Latin luere to atone for, Greek lyein to loosen, dissolve, destroy

def.dt: :to bring to destruction used chiefly in passive construction the ship was lost on the reef
:damn if he shall gain the whole world and lose his own soul Matthew 16:26(Authorized Version)
:to miss from one's possession or from a customary or supposed place
:to suffer deprivation of :part with especially in an unforeseen or accidental manner
:to suffer loss through the death or removal of or final separation from (a person)
:to fail to keep control of or allegiance of lose votes lost his temper
:to fail to use :let slip by :waste no time to lose
:to fail to win, gain, or obtain lose a prize lose a contest
:to undergo defeat in lost every battle
:to fail to catch with the senses or the mind lost what she said
:to cause the loss of
:to fail to keep, sustain, or maintain lost my balance
:to cause to miss one's way or bearings lost himself in the maze of streets
:to make (oneself) withdrawn from immediate reality lost herself in daydreaming
:to wander or go astray from lost his way
:to draw away from :outstrip lost his pursuers
:to fail to keep in sight or in mind
:to free oneself from :get rid of dieting to lose weight
:regurgitate vomit often used in such phrases as lose one's lunch
:to undergo deprivation of something of value
:to undergo defeat lose with good grace
:to run slow
:to suffer loss or disadvantage :fail to advance or improve
:to fail to maintain a hold on reality
:to go crazy
:to become overwhelmed with strong emotion :lose one's composure so angry I almost lost it
:to fall in love
:presenting two options both of which put one at a disadvantage a lose–lose proposition
:to fail to win in competition :fail to receive an expected reward or gain
